question: Question_04_(d)
statement:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this
diagram:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH307_April_2012_Question_04.png}
\end{description}

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges
(resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers.
Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let \emph{D} be the incidence
matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges)
and let \emph{L} be the Laplacian.

\textbf{(d)} Write down the Laplacian \emph{L}.
sols:
The formula for the Laplacian matrix L is\[L = D^{T} R^{-1} D\]

But we can simply calculate the Laplacian matrix by computing the
following:

For the diagonal entries
($L_{ii}$)\[L_{ii} = \sum_{connected \ edges, i} \gamma_{i}\]

For the non-diagonal edges
($L_{ij}$)\[L_{ij} = \sum_{shared \ edges j} \gamma_{j}\] if there are
shared edges and $L_{ij} = 0$ if no shared edges

$\gamma = \frac{1}{R}$ Where R is the resistance of the edge. which in
this question $R = 1$ so $\gamma = 1$.

Following the equations given above, the Laplacian matrix
is\[L = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ 
-1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ 
-1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 
0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}\]

The columns of matrix L are labeled as node 1 to 6 from left to right.

FINAL ANSWER

$L = \begin{bmatrix}
4 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 0\\ 
-1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1 & -1 & 4 & -1 & 0 & -1\\ 
-1& 0 & -1 & 4 & -1 & -1\\ 
-1& -1 & 0 & -1 & 4 & -1\\ 
0 & -1 & -1 & -1 & -1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}$
